Partial Information Kernel-Damping

Source: R/partial_information.R
kernel_entropy.Rd

This function uses entropy-pooling to find the probability mass that can constrain the first two moments while imposing the minimal structure in the data.

kernel_entropy(x, mean, sigma = NULL)

# S3 method for default
kernel_entropy(x, mean, sigma = NULL)

# S3 method for numeric
kernel_entropy(x, mean, sigma = NULL)

# S3 method for matrix
kernel_entropy(x, mean, sigma = NULL)

# S3 method for ts
kernel_entropy(x, mean, sigma = NULL)

# S3 method for xts
kernel_entropy(x, mean, sigma = NULL)

# S3 method for tbl_df
kernel_entropy(x, mean, sigma = NULL)

# S3 method for data.frame
kernel_entropy(x, mean, sigma = NULL)

Arguments

x

An univariate set of risk-drivers.
mean

A number in which the kernel should be centered.
sigma

A number with the uncertainty around mean. When NULL, only the mean is constrained.

Value

A tibble with the new probabilities distribution.

References

De Santis, G., R. Litterman, A. Vesval, and K. Winkelmann, 2003, Covariance matrix estimation, Modern investment management: an equilibrium approach, Wiley.

Examples

ret <- diff(log(EuStockMarkets[ , 1]))
mean <- -0.01 # scenarios around -1%
sigma <- var(diff(ret))

kernel_entropy(ret, mean, sigma)

#> # Fully-Flexible Probability
